fullProgramDescription: The Department of Economics offers a comprehensive undergraduate major leading to a Bachelor of Arts degree in Economics. The program is designed to provide students with a thorough understanding of economic theory, econometrics, and applied economics, as well as the opportunity to explore a range of specialized fields within the discipline. The major prepares students for a variety of careers in fields such as finance, government, and research, as well as for graduate study in economics and related fields.
shortProgramDescription: The Economics B.A. at UC San Diego provides a rigorous foundation in economic theory and applied economics, preparing students for diverse careers or further study.
classHighlights: The Economics Department requires students to complete a series of core courses, including Principles of Microeconomics (ECON 1), Principles of Macroeconomics (ECON 2), Intermediate Microeconomics (ECON 100A), Intermediate Macroeconomics (ECON 100B), and Econometrics (ECON 120A-B or ECON 120C). These courses provide a foundation in microeconomic and macroeconomic theory, as well as econometric methods.

Students must also complete a series of upper-division electives, including at least four upper-division economics courses. These electives allow students to explore a range of specialized fields, such as international trade, monetary economics, and economic development.

The department offers a range of courses that provide students with the opportunity to explore applied economics, including courses in economic history, economic development, and the economics of particular industries or regions.
learningOutcomes: Understand and apply microeconomic and macroeconomic theory to analyze economic phenomena.
Use econometric methods to analyze data and estimate economic relationships.
Analyze the impact of economic policies and institutions on economic outcomes.
Communicate complex economic ideas in a clear and concise manner.
Apply economic principles to real-world problems and issues.
creditRequirements: 180 total quarter units, including major requirements and general education
additionalInformation: The Economics Department requires students to complete a set of core courses, as well as a series of upper-division electives. Students are encouraged to consult with department advisors to plan their course of study.
